abstract: Requiring JPMorgan Chase to admit to violations of securities laws in the case of the so-called London Whale could be a guide for how the S.E.C. would handle such Wall Street cases, the author writes.
snippet: Requiring JPMorgan Chase to admit to violations of securities laws in the case of the so-called London Whale could be a guide for how the S.E.C. would handle such Wall Street cases, the author writes.
lead_paragraph: Trades by the so-called London Whale have already cost JPMorgan Chase over $6 billion in losses. They could also result in a precedent that will make the transactions live on in the annals of notoriety, if the Securities and Exchange Commission can extract an admission of wrongdoing from the bank.

headline.main: For S.E.C., Any JPMorgan Settlement Could Serve as a Template
